briefOverview: The revelation revokes earlier assignments due to disobedience, reissues travel directives to Missouri, and pronounces woes on uncharitable rich and unrighteous poor while blessing the contrite poor.
summary: The Lord warns that salvation requires taking up the cross and obeying His commands, asserting His right to command and revoke as He sees fit. Prior instructions pairing Thomas B. Marsh with Ezra Thayre and Selah J. Griffin with Newel Knight are revoked because of rebellion among the Saints in Thompson, Ohio. Marsh is now to travel quickly to Missouri with Selah J. Griffin, while Newel Knight remains to lead any contrite members who will go. Ezra Thayre is commanded to repent of pride and selfishness and to obey a prior command regarding the land where he lives; otherwise he will be repaid his money but cut off from the Church. If Joseph Smith must pay money related to the situation, the Lord promises he will be repaid in Missouri, with inheritances allotted according to deeds. The Lord rebukes the people for seeking counsel in their own ways and condemns both uncharitable rich and greedy, idle poor, while blessing the poor who are pure in heart with future deliverance and inheritance as the Lord comes to reward every person.
externalContext: In mid-1831, early Latter-day Saints in Ohio were organizing under the law of consecration and preparing to gather to Missouri, identified as the land of Zion. The Thompson, Ohio branch included recent converts who had relocated as a group and faced instability over land and stewardship arrangements. Earlier revelations paired missionaries and leaders for travel to Missouri and assigned stewardship over properties, but noncompliance and disputes disrupted these plans. The revocation and reissuance of assignments here reflect adaptive governance during the church’s rapid early expansion and the practical challenges of consecrated settlement.
externalReferences: “Take up his cross” echoes Jesus’ call to discipleship (Matthew 16:24; Luke 9:23). “Heaven and earth shall pass away, but my words shall not pass away” parallels Jesus’ eschatological assurance (Matthew 24:35; Luke 21:33). “The harvest is past, the summer is ended, and we are not saved” quotes Jeremiah 8:20. The promise that the Lord comes with recompense and will reward every person resonates with Isaiah 40:10 and Revelation 22:12, and themes of the contrite “pure in heart” and inheriting the earth recall Matthew 5:5, 8; compare also Romans 2:6.
practicalQuestions: How do I respond when God’s directions change due to others’ actions or my own—do I still move forward in obedience?
Where might pride or selfishness be shaping my decisions about property, money, or calling, and how will I repent?
Am I generous with my resources, and do I prioritize the needs of the poor in practical, measurable ways?
If I lack means, is my heart still contrite and my hands willing to labor rather than grasp at others’ goods?
Do I seek to counsel in my own ways, or do I actively submit my plans to God’s guidance?
uncertainAreas: The specific details of the prior revoked commandments (pairings and land arrangements) and the precise situation about “the place upon which he lives” and related payments are not fully explained in the chapter; the scope of “lands for their inheritance” is also somewhat ambiguous without broader historical context.
